bestBHT.bht: The centurion's decision to spare the lives of all prisoners, influenced by Paul, produced a remarkable outcome: every soul safely reached land, without the need for a miracle. The meticulous and nautical narrative strongly suggests that the writer, likely the beloved physician, was on board during the shipwreck. Paul's extraordinary influence and the centurion's awareness of his significance played a crucial role in the decision to stay them from their purpose. This episode underscores the gratitude owed to Paul and showcases the wisdom behind the command given.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The centurion, c.—Great must have been the influence of Paul over the centurion's mind to produce such an effect.
All followed the swimmers in committing themselves to the deep, and according to the divine pledge and Paul's confident assurance given them, every soul got safe to land—yet without miracle.

The graphic minuteness of this narrative of the shipwreck puts it beyond doubt that the narrator was himself on board, the great number of nautical phrases, which all critics have noted, along with the unprofessional air which the whole narrative wears, agrees singularly with all we know and have reason to believe of 'the beloved physician.'
Albert Barnes: Thus, for the sake of this one righteous man, the lives of all were spared.
Paul’s being on board was the means of saving the lives of many prisoners.
God often confers important blessings on the wicked for the sake of the pious relatives, friends, and neighbors with whom they are connected.
Philip Schaff: This is singularly true to the spirit of the whole course of the narrative.
We have here a new indication of the charm and power which St. Paul exercised over the minds of those with whom he came in contact.
It seems that Julius was very willing that the other prisoners should have been killed, but he wished to secure the safety of Paul.
Archibald T. Robertson: And no wonder for the centurion knew now how much they all owed to Paul.
This classic verb εξειμ occurs four times in Acts and nowhere else in the N.T. It was a wise command.
John Gill: Not only because he was a Roman citizen, but because he perceived he was some extraordinary person; and chiefly because he was moved there unto by a superior influence
Kept them from their purpose; would not suffer them to execute their design, restrained them from it, and laid his commands upon them to the contrary.

And commanded that they which could swim, should cast themselves first into the sea, and get to land; which some restrain to the Roman soldiers...though it may be, he might chiefly regard the soldiers, who were usually learned to swim...

bhtAttempts.bht: The centurion in Acts 27:43 was greatly influenced by Paul, as evidenced by his decision to spare the lives of all the prisoners on the ship. By listening to Paul's confident assurance and trusting in the divine pledge, every soul on board was able to reach land safely. It is clear from the vivid and detailed account of the shipwreck that the narrator, likely the beloved physician, was present on the ship. The command given by the centurion to stay them from their purpose was a wise one, and it ultimately led to the preservation of everyone's life. This episode demonstrates both Paul's remarkable influence over others and the protection that God provides for the righteous, even in dire circumstances.

The incredible influence of Paul over the centurion can be seen in Acts 27:43 when the centurion spared the lives of all prisoners on board the ship. Paul's confident assurance and the divine pledge assured every soul's safe arrival to land. The detailed and nautical narrative suggests that the writer, likely the beloved physician, was present during the shipwreck. The centurion's command to stay them from their purpose was wise and resulted in the preservation of everyone's life. This passage underscores Paul's influence and God's protection in challenging situations.

The centurion's decision to spare the lives of all prisoners on board the ship, influenced by Paul, led to their safe arrival on land. The meticulous account of the shipwreck indicates that the writer, possibly the beloved physician, was present during the event. By commanding them to stay from their purpose, the centurion displayed wisdom and ensured the preservation of all lives. This incident highlights Paul's remarkable impact on others and demonstrates how God's protection extends to the righteous, even in dire circumstances.

This incident showcases Paul's remarkable influence over others and illustrates God's protection of the righteous, even in perilous situations.

The centurion's decision to spare the lives of all prisoners, influenced by Paul, produced a remarkable outcome: every soul safely reached land, without the need for a miracle. The meticulous and nautical narrative strongly suggests that the writer, likely the beloved physician, was on board during the shipwreck. Paul's extraordinary influence and the centurion's awareness of his significance played a crucial role in the decision to stay them from their purpose. This episode underscores the gratitude owed to Paul and showcases the wisdom behind the command given.
